properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Locally dense fog tonight. Locally dense fog has developed over the area early tonight. This fog will last for most of the night, but should slowly lift with time. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-14T14:02:01-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow will continue tonight. Over the Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, rain will change to snow near the summit tonight. Snowfall amounts near 10 cm is expected tonight before the snow tapers to flurries Wednesday morning. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-14T14:34:18-00:00

Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall expected tonight. Snow will continue tonight as a frontal system continues to track across the B.C. interior. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected tonight before the snow tapers to flurries Wednesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain to continue into this afternoon. Total rainfall: 20 to 45 mm with locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 50 km/h. Locations: northern, southern and eastern New Brunswick. Time span: into this afternoon. Remarks: Rain at times heavy will continue this morning, tapering to showers this afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure system will continue to track across the B.C. interior tonight bringing strong winds through the Fraser Canyon. Winds will rise to southerly 60 km/h gusting to 90 early this evening and ease late this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-14T14:36:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-13T22:37:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2812091946.2020
Area: Fraser Canyon - south including Lytton
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Les Su√™tes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum Les Suetes gusts: 110 km/h. Time span: strengthening this morning then slowly diminishing in the afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Les Su√™tes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Total rainfall: 35 to 50 mm. Locations: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity. Time span: near noon today to early Thursday morning. Remarks: Rain will begin near noon today and become heavy, at times, this evening. The rain is expected to taper off early Thursday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-10-14T23:37:34-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Snow will continue tonight. Snow will continue tonight near the summit of the Okanagan Connector - Merritt to kelowna and Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass as a frontal system tracks across the B.C. interior. Approximately 10 to 15 cm of snow has already fallen with a further 10 cm expected tonight. The snow will taper to flurries Wednesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-14T14:35:32-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Heavy snow, strong winds, and blowing snow will cause near blizzard conditions today. Near blizzard conditions will develop this morning as the wind strengthens and heavy snow begins to fall, resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. 5 to 10 cm of snowfall is expected today, with wind gusts near 90 km/h this morning. This evening, the wind will decrease and the snow will ease, allowing the visibility in blowing snow to improve. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-15T00:26:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-14T08:27:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2502513959.2020

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly 120 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: this afternoon and evening Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds will increase this morning to reach gusts to 120 km/h near noon today. Winds will ease upon shifting to westerly after midnight tonight. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain over Eastern Quebec today: 40 to 50 millimetres are expected. Wednesday, a low pressure system will track across the Gulf of St. Lawrence. The rain will be heavier in the morning over the tip of the Gaspe Peninsula. Over the Lower North Shore, the rain will intensify in the afternoon. Strong southeasterly winds will also be present. Heavy rain may cause flash floods and ponding on roads. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
